qas.question: When did the FBI become concerned about Civil Rights?
What ties did the FBI believe civil rights leaders had?
Who did Hoover send an open letter denouncing?
What agency had Dr. T.R.M. Howard criticized?
What was the controversial domestic surveillance operation in this era?
When did FBI officials become less concerned about Civil Rights?
What ties did civil rights leaders believe the FBI had?
When did Dr. T.R.M. Howard send an open letter denouncing Hoover?
What controversial domestic surveillance program did the CIA carry out?
What was not one of the targets of COINTELPRO?

context: During the <a0_0><b5_0>1950s and 1960s<b5_0/><a0_0/>, FBI officials became increasingly concerned about the influence of civil rights leaders, whom they believed had <a1_0><b6_0>communist ties<b6_0/><a1_0/> or were unduly influenced by them. In <b7_0>1956<b7_0/>, for example, Hoover sent an open letter denouncing <a2_0>Dr. T.R.M. Howard<a2_0/>, a civil rights leader, surgeon, and wealthy entrepreneur in Mississippi who had criticized <a3_0>FBI<a3_0/> inaction in solving recent murders of George W. Lee, Emmett Till, and other blacks in the South. The FBI carried out controversial domestic surveillance in an operation it called the <a4_0><b8_0>COINTELPRO<b8_0/><a4_0/>, which was short for "COunter-INTELligence PROgram." It was to investigate and disrupt the activities of dissident political organizations within the United States, including both militant and non-violent organizations. Among its targets was the <b9_0>Southern Christian Leadership Conference<b9_0/>, a leading civil rights organization with clergy leadership.
